Github

My first proper C++ game, the Engine is built for this project specifically. I implemented several gameplay features, including AABB collision detection, physics, a particle system, and UI using ImGUI. The goal of this project is to deepen my knowledge of C++ beyond using Unreal Engine.

Loading...
Loading..
Loading..

In addition to simple movement the player also has the ability to dash.

Player Movement

One of my primary goals for this project was to create a simple physics system and develop an enjoyable player controller. I added dampening that changes based on if the player is grounded, similar to friction.

The dash was initially programmed to be velocity-direction-based to give the player as much control over their character as possible. However, I later reprogrammed it to be based on the current mouse direction, as it was easier for new players to pick up and use. 

Loading...
Loading...

Trail component being showcased on enemies.

Trail System

The trail system pushes new vertex points to the trail mesh and then updates it. By taking their position in the list and using that position togheter with an easing function we can determine a y position offset that makes the trail pointy.

Loading...

Game Class

The Game class is responsible for managing all the entitys currently in memory, updating and rendering them, and spawning new entitys. Its also handles collisions detection between entitys using AABB checks.

Entitys spawning.

Loading...
Loading..

Reflection

This project has been an incredibly valuable learning experience. When I started, I had limited experience working with pure C++. Throughout the project, I gained proficiency in using essential libraries, managing memory effectively, and writing optimized, efficient code.

As a result, I now feel confident in my ability to write C++ code and am excited to continue building on the knowledge I‚Äôve gained.
